div.head: TANZIM DEPARTMENT AND CAIRO.
div.p: In our last issue we mentioned that the inhabitants of Helouan, weary of the absolute contempt with which the Tanzim. Department treated their just complaints, had determined to appeal directly to Lord Cromer. But it is not. Helouan alone which suffers from the neglect and indifference of the Tanzim Department. Cairo has also grounds for complaint, and it must be admitted that the maintenance of the streets of the Capital is not carried out with such a regard for the convenience of the public as it would be only reasonable to expect. No one, who knows anything at all of the conditions of life in the city and of the always increasing flood of traffic that poury through its streets all day long, will deny that on the whole this work is well done, for though it might, we should imagine, be easily expedited when 'tis done, 'tis well done, but there is a want of tact in the choice of time and place for the labours of the department in charge that is not merely annoying to the average man in the street, but a very serious impediment to the business of the town. At the present moment Clot Bey-street has been pulled up from one end to the other and all traffic throughout it is completely stopped. In fact this has been the case for more than a month past, with the single qualification that the Tramway Company has continued to use its lines through the street. Those lines carry an immense aniount of traffic, seeing that they form part of the 'direct tramway routes to Abbassieh, Rod-el-Farag, and Shoubris, and form the connecting link between the milway station and the Mousky, Nasrieb, and, in short, all parts of the town. Fortunately for the ordinary carriage traffic the closing of this street is not a great inconvenience inas -much as the alternative route by the Bab el Hadeed street adds but little to the distance to be covered. With the tramways, however, the case is different, for the whole of the traffic that usually goes through Clot Bey has now to make a long detour passing by the Post Office, Continental Hotel, and so on up the Boalse road and thence along the new road to the railway station. The consequence of this is that all day long a double stream of traimoars is passing right through the heart of the town and crosses. the heavy carriage traffic that is always in motion to and from the Sharia Kamel and the south and west parts of the town. Happily both the Boalse road and the approaches to it from the east are wide enough to easily meet the strain thus put upon them, or rather they would be so if it had not been that just at this particular moment one half of the Boulse road has been torn up and is being remacadamised in the leisurely manner to which we are acoust omed. Why this work, which most certainly was not pressingly needed, should have been undertaken exactly at the time that the opening of the season brings a rush of traffic to this spot, and that that rush is already spore or less seriously incommoded by the abnormal tram way traffic, is a question that it would pale any sane man to answer, unless the answer be that the authorities are quite indifferent to the convenience of the public or are, for some rea son or other, incapable of judging its needs It is really therefore to be hoped that some steps will be taken to place some one in charge of the organisation and working of the depart ment responsible who is competent to carry it on without exhibiting the utter indifference to! the convenience of the public that is shown at present
Open all the year round. ELEOBRIG LIGHT.-LIFT.-ODERATE CHARGER

div.head:
THE WAR.
RUSSIAN BOMBARDMENT.
JAPANESE REPULSE
GREAT BATTLE IMMINENT

div.p: A stiff artillery fire was opened on the Russian right at daylight, and lasted for several hours. The fire continued at intervals during the day. The Russians are expecting a general attack. All ranges have been carefully marked, and whichever any attacks is likely to suffer severely.. (Reuter.)
The Hussians expect a general attack. (H.)
The Russian artillery on the Sha Ho have ompelled the Japanese to fell back. (Hans).

Friday's report from Marshal Oyama, detail- ing the various skirmishes and stating that the Russian bombardment of the Japanese positions was resultless, seems to indicate the imminence of another great battle, though, apparently, neither side has yet made any decisive move- ment. The Russian feints were evidently intended to draw the Japanese (Reiter.)

The attack on Putiloff, mentioned on 18th inst., was made in order to ascertain the strength of the Russian position. The Japanese got within 30 yards of the trenches, but were finally repulsed leaving 100 dead. (Beuter.)

div.head:
THE UNITED STATES.
THE PRESIDENT'S MESSAGE.
PEACE CONFERENCE,
NAVAL AMBITION.

div.p: It is understood that Mr. Roosevelt's message will say nothing regarding tariff reform, but the party leaders are carefully considering a revision which will be proposed next year. Nearly all the European powers have indicat ed their acceptance in principle of Mr. Hay's invitation for a Peace Conference, leaving the details for future negotiations
The United States Naval Estimates for 1905 amount to 114,5000,000 dollars, which is an increase of 17,000,000. (Reuter)
Mr. Morton, Secretary for the Navy, speaking here, declared that Mr. Roosevelt aimed at having the best and strongest Navy in the (Reuter)

div.head: ANGLO-RUSSIAN CONVENTION. NEGOTIATIONS PROGRESSING.
div.p: The Anglo-Russian negotiations for the Con vention are progressing. Russia desires to exclude anything which would imply that the Russians are necessarily to blame. (Router)

div.head: JAPANESE LOAN.
div.p: The total subscriptions for the Japanese - loan here amount to £80,533,800 (Reuter)

div.head: RIO JANEIRO TROUBLES
div.p: Colonel Sadre, the instigator of the troubles, has given himself up to the authorities. (H.)

div.head: STRIKE DISTURBANCES AT HAVRE
div.p: Disturbances have taken place as a result of the strike of port labourers

div.head:
PORT ARTHUR.
ATTACK RECOMMENCED.
MAGAZINE EXPLODED.
JAPANESE SUCCESS

div.p: General Stoessel telegraphs that all the assaults up to the 15th inst. have been repulsed. (Havas)
The Japanese recommenced the attack on Port Arthur on Thursday. They destroyed the powder magazine
It is reported that the Japanese, after success fal mining, have occupied the counterscarp of the Sang su-shan fort

The Japanese Headquarters at Port Arthur report that a shell from a naval gun exploded a magazine near the Arsenal yesterday. The operations against all forts are proceeding as Previously arranged. (Reuter.)

div.head:
THE BALTIC FLEET.
GOING TO VLADIVOSTOK.
div.p: The Russian authorities consider that the Baltic Fleet, will sot be handicapped by the capture of Port Arthur. Even should the fortress hold out the fleet will, in any case, proceed to Vladivostok, as small hopes are entertained of the effectiveness of the Port Artur fleet. (Heuter)

div.head: A POST AND TELEGRAPH OFFICE
div.p: was opened at Geteins on the 3rd November.

div.head: CLOT BET STREET,

div.head:
THE SABA-NAHAS WEDDING
A SPLENDID CEREMONY.
FULL DETAILS
div.p: The marriage of Miss Mary Saba, the daughter of the popalar Postmaster-General of Egypt, to F. Nahas Bey, the great Syrian notable, wais celebrated on Saturday evening with all the splendour and hospitality befitting sach an auspicions social event in the history of Alexandria. The ceremony has been looked forward to for many weeks past by the inha bitants of Egypt's commercial capital, for the popularity of our worthy Postmaster General is widespread, and the magnificence of the fete was Tally in accordance with the high official rank of the family, whose hospitality on this occasion will long be remembered. The invita tions had been sent out for 9.30 p.m. and shortly after that hour the immediate neigh bourhood of that part of Ramleh, where is the palatial residence of Saba Pasha, was alive with a ceaseless procession of carriages bringing the wedding guests. A large number of those invited came also from Alexandria, and cant less tramloads of invités were despatched at intervals of a few minutes from the city ter minus of the line to Halt 1, which is con- veniently situated in proximity to the scene of the festivities.

The road leading to the residence of the Pasha was gorgeously illuminated and bedeck ed with prettily arranged lamps, which gave a fairy-like aspect to the impressive surround- ings. Before the portal giving access to the mansion a great tent had been erected, draped with tastefully-arranged curtains, where at cloak-room had been installed. The immediate approach to the house is by a staircase of marble steps, leading to an entrance hall, through which the guests passed to the great balcony, where a scene of enchanting loveliness met their astonished gaze.

From the balcony to the extreme end of the garden there stretched one huge pavilion, completely composed of Arabie curtains The superficies, covered was very extensive and the flooring consisted of fanumerable Oriental rugs. This vast expanse was relieved by beautiful floral decorations, and numberless tables and chairs had been set out for the convenience of the guests. Throughout the end of this pavilion the supper buffets were spread, and these were concealed by a gigantic curtain until after the wedding ceremony had been gone through.

At 10 o'clock the guests had nearly all arrived and the scene, was animated. in the extreme. The uniforms of the officers of the Army of Occupation and of the naval officers: of the Greek Squadron, the exquisite dresses of the ladies, and the general diversity of the gathering, contributed to make the spectacle most brilliant and entrancing. The most in- teretting moment of the evening was when the bridal procession issued from the house and advanced slowly along the spacious balcony, while Professor D'Ambra's string band struck up the entrancing strains of the Wedding March from Lohengrin. This impressive cor tage was headed by gorgeously caparisoned Ravasses, who were followed by a. group of the high pontiffs of the Syrian Greek Catholic Melchite rite.

The magnificent vestments and elaborately decorated robes of these ecclesiastics presented an admirable coup d'ail. Immediately behind the Vicar-General, the archimandrites, and the priests, the bride followed, leaning on the art of her father. She looked charming and her dress elicited general admiration. Her long train was borne by a lovely little child, garbed in blue.

The bridegroom followed, leaning on Ma dame Saba Pasha's arm. That lady's dress was a creation in ivoire chiffon with appliques. A bevy of bridesmaids, exquisitely dressed, follow- ed, led by Mr. Saba and Miss Tagher, dark beauty in a pale blue dress. The cortège advanced down the steps, while the guests silently and respectfully fell back to make way for them. As the bridal procession came to wards the spot where the sacred ceremony was to take place, a startling and beautiful effect was produced by the sudden illumination of numberless electric lamps, which were arranged

The actual ceremony was performed in Rocordance with the quaint and solemn rites of the Syrian Greek Catholic Melchite Churche The rubric of this ritual has been handed down from the Bysantine epoch, and the curique chants and elaborate ceremonial are survivals from the earliest era of the Eastern Church. In the absence of the Patriarch of the Syrian Greek Catholic Melchite Church, His Holiness Kyrillos Goha, who is at present at Rome, the marriage ceremony was conducted by the Right Reverend Kyrillos Risk: Vicar General of the Patriarchate

After the ceremony the bride and, brides grooms and Saba Pasha and his wife received the heartiest congratulations of all present. Ices and sweets were then handed round. The bonbons were lavishly distributed among the guests, elaborately arranged in Japanese tine paper tied with pink silk Javours At 11 o'clock the supper buffets were thrown open and an exquisite repast was partaken of by all present

Two thousand invitations had been issued for the marriage; and the throng of welding got was very grist, bet owing to the enormous available space there was no erish. The Khedive was represented by Youssef Pasha Dia, 1st Aide-de-Camp to his Highness. Among those present were Prince Omar Pasha Toussoms, Brig. General Bullock, C. B., and his staff, Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria (who had returned from Cairo that evening spesially in order to be presept), M. Belinfante Ustberg, Diplomatic Agent and Consul General for Sweden and Norway, M. Girard, French Consul, and Mme Girard, Baron von Humboldt-Dachroeden, German Consal, Chevalier Pascarius, Austro-Hungarian Consul, Hassan Pasha Mohsen, Liegt. Col. McCracken, Major and Mrs. Gamble, Captain and Mrs Bingley, Captain and Mrs. Pinch, and the officers of the 2nd Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment, a number of officers from the Hellenie Squadron, Dr. Raffer, Director-General of the Quarantine Board, and, Mrs. Ruffer, Michalla Pasha, Sub-Director General of the Customs Administration, and Mrs. Michalla, Mr. Am broise Ralli, Vice President of the Alexandria Municipality, Mr. Chataway, Administrator of fie Alexandria Municipality, and Mrs. Cha- taway, Mr. Debbane; Consul General for Brazil, Miralai Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of the Alexandria City Police, and the Hon. Mrs. Hopkinson, Zananiri Bey, Secretary-General of the Quarantine Board, and Mrs. Zananiri, Peake Bey, Deputy Postmaster-General, and Mrs. Peake, Dr. Szarvazy, Austro-Hungarisa Vice-Consul, Mr. Jas. Hewat, American Consular Agent, Mr. Borchgrevink, Procureur-General, Mr.Sootidis, Hellenic Consal-General, Hafez Bey Mohamed, Sub Governor of Alexandria, Dr. and Mrs. Morrison, Dr. Gottschlich, Beneducci Bey, Secretary to the Gouvernorst, and Mrs. Beneducci, Mr. and Mrs. G. B. and Miss Alderson, Mohamed Bey Said, Chief of the Native Parquet, M. Reiny, Belgian Consul, Councillors of the Alexandria Municipality, Jadges of the Mixed and Native Tribunals, and a representative gathering of the crème de la crème of the English, Greek, Jewish, German- and French colonies, besides all the leading representatives of Syrian, Coptic, and native society in Alexandria.
Mr. Gould, H.B.M.'s Consul General at Alexandria, was unable to be present owing to a cold.

One of the most remarkable features of this splendid ceremony was the profusion and taste of the floral tributes Throughout the salons of the mansion, all round the walls, festoons of exquisite garlands and wreaths of flower were displayed. The effect was most enchanting. Mr. G. B. Alderson let off fireworks about 10 p.m. in his garden in honour of the mar riage.
The presents were both costly and numerous and included a vast quantity of jewellery and gems.

div.head: SIR W. WILLCOCKS EXPEDITION.
div.p: As Sir William Willcocks has received per- mission from the Turkish Government to exa- mine into the ancient irrigation system on the Tigris and Euphrates, he is leaving to morrow for Bombay en route for Basra and Bagdad, where he hopes to make a preliminary examina tion of the ground this winter.

div.head:
NILE COLD STORAGE CO.
PROGRESS AND PROSPECTS.
div.p: The reserve shares of the Nile Cold Storage Company have had a most successful issue. They were, in fact, largely over applied for. The object of this issue was in order to comply with the desires of the principal share- holders-who are the largest consumers of perishable goods in this country.

The capitalists requested that the company's operations should be extended, and that it should deal in all perishable provisions, and not in meat alone. The company therefore made the above mentioned issue in order to extend its sphere of operations to meet the wishes of these gentlemen.

The Board of the Nile Cold Storage Com- pany has also decided to erect a cold store at Alexandria on a much larger scale than the one already approaching completion at Port Said. This Alexandria cold store will be suffi ciently extensive to store all the provisions that the company will import and yet will still have a large space which can be let out to merchants, hotel proprietors, eto.

The cold store at Cairo will be completed this week, and already the first of a weekly series of shipments of game, poultry, fish, butter, eggs, ete, is en route and will arrive before the end of this month.
The capital of the company is only £50,000, so that the return on this small capital should be large, especially in view of the fact that the largest consumers are interested as share holders. 7

div.head: RAILWAY COMMISSION
div.p: The Railway Commission left Cairo this morning to examine the line between Zagazig and Dessouk. The members will afterwarder go to Tantah, whence they cothe on to Alexandria, arriving here at 6.20 p.m.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE
div.p: Last night, Hamlet, the French composer Thomas's most substantial production, and Mignon, his most genial, were given at the Alhambra and Abbas Helmy Theatre, respect ively. The perfomance of the latter was frantically applauded. The representation was from every point of view excellent. Signs. Monti Baldini fully justified the celebrity which she has acquired on the European stage. It would be dithenit indeed to find a more graceful and perfect Mignon. The prima donna was well seccoded by the tenor Tomiani; who made. his debut last night and met with con alegable access. The other artisten wore all good in their respective roles, while the or chestra worked wonders

div.head: GREEK FLEET'S VISIT.
div.p: The members of the Hellenic Club organised on Saturday afternoon a farewell reception to Commodore Coundouriotis and staff and the officers of the Greek Fleet at 5 o'clock. They were received by the president, Mr. M. Sina dino, surrounded by the other members of the club. A great many members of the Greek community were present, including Mr. and Mrs. E. Benachi, Mr. and Mrs. M. Salvago, Mr. and Mrs. Alex. Benachi, Mr. and Mrs. Delta Mr. and Mrs. N. Sinadino, Dr. and Mrs. Valas- sopoulo: Dancing took place to the strains of the band of the Greek Philharmonic Society and of the flagship Psara.

The proceedings opened by Mr. M. Sinadino proposing the health of the Greek Fleet, which was received with the greatest enthusiasm: In his speech, Mr. Sinadino, on behalf of the meinbers of the club and the Greek community generally, wished the officers and men God- speed on the continuation of their cruise. He asked Commodore Coundouriotis to convey to H. M. the King of the Hellenes the thanks of the community for having sent the fleet to these waters, and expressed the hope, shared by one and all, that this pleasant visit would be the forerunner of others equally pleasant.

Commodore Coundouristis then thanked Mr. Sinadino and the entire community for the very cordial reception which had been extended to the Fleet during its stay here. He said he would have the greatest pleasure in conveying the wish of the community to his Majesty that a return visit might be paid. He only hoped that next time they came they would be stronger in numbers.

Other speakers followed, including M. Gen- nadis, Diplomatie Agent and Consul-General, who also thanked Mr. Sinadino,and the bers of the club for the manner in which they had entertained the Fleet, and wished the Commodore, his officers, and men "bon voyage. The greatest animation prevailed up to a late hour, dancing being engaged in up to 11 p.m.

Mr. and Mrs. Em. Benachi subsequently gave a dinner party at their residence in the Greek quarter to the departing Commodore and officers. Amongst the guests were Mr. Gerandis, Hellenie Diplomatie. Agent, Mr. N. Seotidis, Consul General, and the leading members of the Hellenic community, viz., Mr. and Mrs. M. Sinadino, Mr. and Mrs. M. Sal- vago, Mr. and Mrs. 8. Delta, Mr. and Mrs. Alex. Benachi, and Mr. G. Zervudachi. After dinner a reception followed at which nearly, all of Hellenic society was present. Dancing continued until the early bours of the morning.
Yesterday morning, Mass was celebrated on board the Spetzai, at which about a hundred civilians assisted. These were afterwards enter tained by Capt. Caloyanni and his officers-

Yesterday afternoon, the harbour of Alex- andria, on the occasion of the departure of the fleet, was the scene of unwonted movement and animation. Early in the afternoon large numbers of people collected on the quay and sailed out in small boats to witness from near the departure of the ships. A small steamer be longing to Mr. Minotto was also kindly lent to carry the members of the committee of re- ception, besides a quantity of other people and the band of the Philharmonic society. At about 3.30 p.m. the Hydra weighed anchor and commenced to steam slowly out of the harbour. Her departure was greeted with loud and prolonged cheers, the band of the Philharmonie playing the Greek Anthem, as well as the band of the warship. As the Hydra steamed towards the entrance of the harbour, she was followed by Mr. Minotto's steamer and in- numerable small sailing boats, crammed with enthusiastic and excited crowds, who greeted the departure of the vessel with continued and repeated cheers. On the steam launch we remarked, besides the Diplomatic repre sentative of Greece, M. Gennadis, and the Consul-General, M. Scotidis, all the leading members of the Greek colony here, M. E Benschi, M. M. Sinadino, M. & Salvago, M. G. Zervudachi, M. J. Cartalis,and many others, most also with their wives and children. The enthusiasm and excitement manifested on the launch were great. Mr. Minotto himself climb ed on to one of the masts and saluted from thence the departing ship. When the Hydra reiched the entrance of the harbour, the accompanying steamer and boats returned, and in like manner escorted the warship Spetsi out of the harbour. The flagship Psara was the last to leave, amidst an uproar of cheers, shouting, waying of hats, and, the playing of music.

The beautiful weather added to thebright hess and animation of the scene, and it being a Sunday afternoon, large numbers of the working classes also had collected to witness the departure. It may be remarked that the Greek colony, as on all preceding occa afons, also manifested on this final one that patriotism and enthusiasm regarding their fleet which cannot but impress the observer, and prove to him the close and powerful ties which exist between the mother country, Greece pro- per, and the rich and powerful Greek colony in Bgypt.

It may be remarked that throughout the whole stay of the fleet here, there has not been cited a single example of disorderly or bad confuet among the Greek sailors when in the town, a fact which reflects the highest credit on the discipline and good conduct both of the officers and men.
Yesterday evening, at the Greek Club here most of the leading members of the Greek colony met and discussed the means of raising the sum which is to be contributed towards the fleet.
Port Said, Monday-The Greek Squadron has arrived. The ships were welcomed by enthusiastic crowds on launches and on the breakwater

div.head: THE ROYAL BERKS
div.p: Two companies of the 2nd Battalion Boyal Berkshire Regiment, left to-day for Abonkir, where they will camp out for a week's training

The three companies of the regiment which are going to Cairo, will leave on December 2, by the troop train which will have brought the 20th Hussars to Alexandris for embarkation. The approximate strength of the three com- panies is 330 men. They will be quartered at Abbassieh

div.p: With regard to the agreement to be come to between the Government and the K. A. S., we understand that its terms are now drawn up and will shortly be submitted to a meeting of the society.

div.p: The Canard SS. Cypria sailed yesterday for Liverpool with full cargo of 4,605, bales cotton, 846 tons cotton seed, etc.

div.head: FREEMASONRY AT TANTAH.
div.p: A very interesting ceremony took place on Saturday evening at Tantah, namely, the consegration of a new Masonic lodge under the English Constitution. This lodge is passed the Delta No. 3060 W. Bro: Langley, of the DG. L of Egypt and the Sadan, assisted by W, Bros Clifton, Delanoy, Lambton, Ablitt and Bent, most worthily carried out this in- teresting ceremony. The brethren from the Alexandria lodges turned up in strong force to assist in giving this, the youngest, lodge in Egypt under the English Constitution a hearty start.
After the ceremony a banquet was held in the Pelta Railway Institute, kindly lent for the occasion.

div.head: MIXED TRIBUNAL
div.p: The technical commission for the revision of the Codes as applied to the Mixed Tribunals, and reforms in the working of certain branches of these tribunals, has begun its sittings at the Mixed Tribunals, under the presidency of Boutros Pasha Ghali, Minister for Foreign Affairs.

div.head: NILE BOILER EXPLOSION.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZNITE

Dear Six-Having read in your esteemed journal a few days ago of a boiler explosion, which occurred on a steamer lying nose Kate el-Nil Bridge, Cairo, which resulted in the loss: of several lives; I would like through the mediam of this paper to enquire why the boilers and engines of river steamers are not put under compulsory inspection by the Pablio Works Department, seeing that boilers and engines on land are under compulsory super vision of the Department.

To the man in the street this appears a most absurd arrangement as it stands at prest To say nothing of the very apparent ty for official inspection of boilers and engines of river craft, it is a well known fade to engineers engaged in repairing such steamers, that there are a considerable number of steamers (if snol they can be called) working on the Nile, that are, with respect to their boilers, a greater menage to those who are employed on them and to any craft, that come near them, than any floating mine yet designed. The writer knows the existence of small craft on the Nile which are equipped with boilers the age of which must be sought for in the long-forgotten past. Surely our Government in Brypt can put their foot firmly, down now and demand the compulsory inspection of these craft by competent and responsible officials.

According to statements appearing in the local papers since the disaster, she boiler which exploded recently had been subjected to an overhaul a short time before, but this does not do away with the necessity for inspection. F think I may say that the owners of river steamers themselves should be the first to wel come official inspection, and morally speaking so they should do both for their own intereste and the interests of those employed on them and who travel on them.
I sincerely hope this incident will be the mes of drawing public attention and the attention of the Government to the immediate necessity of placing river steamers under com pulsory inspection.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The widows of the late Khedive Ismail arriv ed at Cairo yesterday morning from Constanti nople.

The correspondent of the Times at Rome writing on the 9th inst., pays the following tribute to Sir Bennell Rodd:- "Very great regret is felt in all quarters here at the depart ure of Sir Rennell Rodd, the new Minister at Stockholm, who leaves Rome to-morrow. Dur ing his three years' service, ai Secretary of the Embassy, he has gained, not only the respect bat also the affection of all who have come in contact with him; and this has been partienlarly the case with the Italian official world, who have always had for him a very high and marked esteem."
Mr. P. Hashim, chef de bureau of the Public Security Department at the Alexandria Gouvernorst, has been promoted to the post of chef de bureau at the Ministry of Interior.

div.head: QUESTIONS MUNICIPALES
div.p: Il manquait à notre Municipalité, pour être complète, un corps de police spécial Cette lacune, à peine signalée, vient d'être comblée. Déjà la Délégation et le Gouver noral se sont occupée du nombre et du salaire de ce noavesa personnel. Il ne reste plus qu'à soumettre la proposition à la Commission Municipale. Quelles vont être les attributions de cette police indépen dante, de cet Etat dans l'Etat, nous avons eu soin de le 'demander. Si nos informat tions sont exsetes, ce corps est destiné à prêter main forte sax percepteurs municipaax, en ce qui concerne en particulier la laze da 20/0. Cet impôt que le contribu able sisé paie sans difficulté, le pauvre est obligé quelquefois de le refuser. C'est à quoi va servir la nouvelle police. Les dé bris de meubles de es malheureux seront vendus séance tenante et toutes les mesures de rigueur qui sont permises par la loi, impitoyablement appliquées.

Comme à ce trait on reconnait bien l'esprit qui anime notre Municipalité! Bi cette conduite odieuse pouvait augmenter de façon notable, les recettes de la ville, passe encore. Mais cette armée de pereepteurs civile, flu quée d'une armée de poi diers, ocossionners des frais plus considé rables que le produit des te même. N serait-it pas plus économique en mé ne temps que plas humanitaire, sinon d'rinnérer de la taxe ces malheureux payant un faible loyer, du moins de laisser les choos en l'état où elles sont ?

Nous connaissons trop malheureusement les tendanes de nos conseillers pour douter un moment qu'ils ne snetionnent Is mesure proporés par la Délégation. Ils ont tonjours déployé beaucoup de sèl pour ls perception des impôs it wile avaient montré la même rigu ur dans l'adminis tration des dépenses, ils ne mériteraient que des éloges.

Nous aurons done une police municipale C'est une affaire entendae et qui sera décidée à l'ananimité comme l'a été l'exelusion de la presse des séances, comme va l'être bientôt le renvoi de la question des maisons ouvrières sax calendes grecque. Au moins nons sera-t-il permis de suggérer à notre Manicipalité une oeupation plas utile pour cette police que la poursuite de malheureus, nous voulons dire la mise en vigueur d'un système de poids et meares poinçonnés, fabriqués par l'Etat et délivrés Aux marchands contre le prix de facture, Ce serait rendre aux pauvres un peu de cette justio qui lear est cons'amment refasée que d'obliger sinei les détaillants à lede livrer le poids exset. Les bacals, les marchands de légumes et de poissons, les boulang is, les boashses, ata on, en eff des poids inférieurs de 15 20 0/0 an pid légal. div.head:
ZUBAIR PASHA.
HIS AUTOBIOGRAPHY.
div.p: It is in the Darfur campaign that Zubair's career gets mixed up with those events that have led to the interest of England in the Sudan, While Zubair was conquering Darfur, the Governor of Khartoum, Ismail Pasha Ayyoub, was sent to Darfur by the Khedive to Assist in the conquest; probably, as some of Gordon's biographers assert, to prevent Zubair being too independent. The latter asserts that be had achieved his work when Ismail proffer ed his assistance; that nevertheless he wel- comed the Khedive's emissary'st Fasher, the capital of Darfur, and discharged a hundred guns in his honour; that he handed over the government of the conquered countries to Ismail Ayyoub, proceeding himself with a picked force to deal with the relics of the defeated armies. With these be easily esme to terms, but a dispute broke out on his return to Fasher between himself and Ismail Ayyoub with respect to a propo sition that the son of the late Sultan of Darfur should be made governor of the province, subject to the Khedive, and to pay £100,000 annually, a proposal favoured by Zubair. but rejected by Imail Ayyoub. Zubair, was, however, entrusted with the command of an expedition to quell a rebellion got up by a gon of the deceased Sultan; and in this, his last expedition, he advanced as far sa Wadai, whence, however, he was summarily recalled. He then asked leave to return to Cairo to interview the Khedive, and received in reply an invitation to do so, sccompanied with the title Pasha. He brought as sent to his master 1000 Sudanese soldiers, completely armed, 100 Arab horses, 8 tons of ivory of the finest quality, four lions, four panthers, and twelve parrots." But in spite of his munificence he was not allowed to return to the Sudan, and the defence of his kingdom passed to his son Suleiman, whom Gordon some years after caught and abot.

Portions of this narrative certainly bear some resemblance to the adventures of Sindbad the Sailor; yet in the main it corresponds well with the records of Junker and Nachtigal, while it contains many details unknown to them. Throughout Zabair appears as what Wingate (1) describes him, a born leader of men. The reputation which he enjoyed in the Sadan, and which nine years after he had been exiled, from it would have sufficed, in Gordon's well-grounded opinion, to keep the Sudanese from joining the Mahdi, was based on his marvellous success in war, but also, it would seem, on the strict justice of his rule, of which he bossts, though he admits that his punishments were occasionally severe, including hanging with the head downwards. The references to him in Gordon's later Journal do not contradict Zubair's description of himself in these respects.

On the other hand, the autobiography affords little justification for the hysterical passage cited above from Birkbeck Hill, the impression produced by which on the British public probably cost the gallant officer his life. Zubair's omission of all mention of the slave trade in his account of his life is doubtless intentional, and his connection with it is too well attested for us to attach moch importance to the omission. But the phrase "riminal of boundless wickedness" is as unanit able as the terin "scoundrel" for a man in the position of Zubair, pursuing a form of traffic which his own religion tolerated, and which, Gordon admits, had been discovered in Europe to be illicit only one generation before From Becker's "Ismailia" it appears that it was difficult to do business in the. Sudan without being a slave trader; and if Zubair con tributed to the desolation of the Sadan, some credit should, on the other hand, be given him for having in places arrested the process by the introduction of strong government. Nor dan we treat his conduct in fomenting a rebellion which might lead to the restoration of his sovereign rights as very heinous. Having conquered some provinces by his own arm, he had then pre sented them to the Khedive, who, rewarded kimh for the gift by interning him in Cairo. Some sympathy is surely due to his son, "the City" in his attempt to say for his family sonde relics out of his father kingdom.

Had Zubair been permitted to return to the Sudan in 1876 or 1894, the history of that vart region would have been different, and much bloodsbed would have been spared at least for a time. The course of events has provided it with a permanent soures of good govern ment, which Zabair could not have given it His autobiography, however, gives by the ground for Gordon's anxiety for his service i 1884, just as Gordon's earlier Letters explai the prejudice by which he was deprived of them. (The Monthly Review) "Made in the Bgyption

div.head:
EGYPT EXPLORATION FUND.
APPEAL FOR SUPPORT.
div.p: The eighteenth ordinary general meeting of the Egypt Exploration Fund was held in the rooms of the Royal Society, Burlington House, it on the 11th inst, when the president, Sir John Evans, took the chair.

After some formal business the Treasurer read his report, expressing regret that it was the most unfavourable he had had to deal with. In regard to the Exploration Fund the total expenditure was £3,084, whereas the receipts C were £1,806. As to the archaeological survey £558 was spent sa against £422 received; th while on the Greco-Roman branch £1,325 was spent and £931 received. There was, there fr fore, a serious deficit. In the case of the fund y proper this arose from the necessity of sending out two expeditions and from the falling off of th receipts from America. The second expedition fo was necessary because the right of priority to excavate outside the temple of Queen Hatshepu A would have otherwise had to be abandoned,- and then they would not through Dr. Naville have found the remains of a temple built prior to that of Queen Hatshepu. The diminution of

was serious, and was due to the fact that fe the Americans were now undertaking inde- pendent excavations. As to the Greco-Roman branch it had been intended to send out an 0 expedition every other year, but the success of the discoveries at Behness put many other searchers in the field and an annual expedition became necessary. Last year Dr. Grenfell and Dr. Hunt, among most important papyri, un- earthed the new Logia, and the epitome of Livy, and next year's work, for which enough money was available, would, it was hoped, w produce something of equal importance. It was pointed out that the ordinary subscription of s guines, after payment of the expenses of the P publications and the, office dues, only left t about three shillings for the purposes of excavation, and an urgent appeal was therefore M made to all subscribers to double their sub- scription at least for the current year, or to make a substantial donation, else the small capital of the fund would have to be drawn on. The accounts were adopted without discussion.

Sir John Evans then delivered his address. After referring to the losses of the society through the deaths of Dr. Stuart Murray, Mr. Edward Gilbertson, the Bishop of Carlisle, Mr. G. F. Watts, R.A., the Rev. Dr. George Salmon, and Sir William T. Charley, K.C., he appealed argently for funds and then summarised the work done in the past season. Professor Flinders Petrie had excavated on the site of Herakleopolis, now Ehnass, sixty miles south of Cairo, and the principal object of interest found was a golden statuette of a local divinity, Hershefi, bearing on its base a dedication by a King of the XXIVth Dynasty, of whom no other relics are known, and a magnificent triad in red granite representing Rameses 11, between the gods Hershefi and Ptah, 11ft. high and 8ft. broad. At Thebes, close to the temple of Queen Hatabepu, Dr. Naville and Mr. Hall had found the mortuary chapel of a King of the XIth Dynasty, who reigned about 2500 s.c. Part IV. of the Oxyrhynchus Papyri had been published, end with it a small volume of the Logia of Jesus. Some of the minor papyri were of much interest.

There was, for instance, a document recording the emancipation of a slave, entering into all the minute particulars of a passport of the middle of the last century. In a deed by which two brothers joined in the manumission of the third part of a slave who as regards the other two parts had already been made free, one brother Achilleus is described of middle height, fair, having a long face and ascaron the middle of his forehead; while the female slave, who to become entirely free Apollonous, aged about twenty six, of middle height, fair-has a long face and a sear on the right foot. Her third part seems to have been worth three handred drachm of silver, say, £10. Some other

were bonds of apprenticeship. One witnessed that a boy named Thorus is apprenticed for five years to learn the art of weaving from Heraclas, who for the first year and seven months is to pay the boy no wages, bat find t him in food and a stipulated quantity of clothes. After the term mentioned the boy is to receive a gradually increasing amount of d wages and more expensive clothes. Twenty holidays in each year are to be allowed on account of festivals, but there is no mention in of "week ends.". The date of this bond is A.D. in 183. Even more remarkable is the bond of of apprenticeship of a slave for two years to the "semiograph, to be taught to read and write shorthand of "the signa that your you Dionysios knows, "the teacher receiving in all the premiums of a hundred and twenty drachme This is dated about A.D. 100.Someprivate letters are interesting, and an invitation of a decurion to his party on the sixth day before the Kalends, at eight o'clock has a distinctly modern flavour.

Lord Cromer, in his report on Egypt for1903, had alluded to their publications, which, he said, showed that many of the abuses which until lately existed in Egypt almost in their original form were of very ancient date.. "For instance, plentiful allusions, are made to the system of tax-farming, which it is well known prevailed in Egypt, as elsewhere, from time immemorial, and which appears everywhere to have given rise to abuses very similar in chs- racter." Lord Cromer then pointed out that with the recent fishery reforms almost the last restige of this iniquitous and oppressive sys tem would disappear. He noted with some in- terest that in the days of Domitian the system -though without doubt equally oppressive to the taxpayers-soned hardly to have been so lucrative to the tax-farmers as in those of Abbas II. These have been of recent years making an annual profit of over £30,000, whereas from the

it appears that on certain taxes being put up to auction those who had previously held the concession not only refused to bid bat seemed likely to abscond, "as they had incur red sufficient. loss already." In the case of slavery, which is still not altogether unknown on the upper waters of the Blue Nile, Lord Cromer compared a recent purchase of a lad of fifteen for £12 with that of a woman, aged thirty-five, for £7 2s. 6d, and inquired whether a slave really cost more on the Abyssinian frontier in 1903 than was paid in Egypt in the year 86. In conclusion, the chairman referred to the irrigation works in Egypt, and hoped that all possible precautions would be taken! for the preservation of monuments within the ares of the extended reservoir should the Assouan dam be heightened.

Subsequently Professor Flinders Petrie and Dr. Bernard Grenfell gave brief accounts of their work and plans for the coming year. Pro- fessor Petrie intends to completely examine Sinai, if permission can be obtained, and Dr. Grenfell will resume the search for papyri at Oxyrhynchus

div.p: Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
